item.title: Head of Poland’s Governing Party Leads a Shift Rightward
item.description: Jaroslaw Kaczynski holds no elective office, but as leader of the governing Law and Justice Party he is the primary force in a rightist consolidation of authority.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Jaroslaw Kaczynski, the leader of the ruling Law and Justice Party in Poland, at a parliamentary session in December. Under Mr. Kaczynski, the party has steered Poland away from its previously Euro-enthusiastic and more liberal stances.

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 10 in Istanbul District of Sultanahmet
item.description: The Turkish president said a Syrian was behind the attack, which killed and wounded both Turks and foreigners.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Rescue teams gathered at the scene of an explosion in Istanbul on Tuesday.

item.title: China Is Said to Formally Arrest 4 Human Rights Advocates
item.description: The move against the four, already detained for six months, continues a nationwide sweep of more than 200 lawyers and associates who worked on civil rights cases.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Li Wenzu, who is married to Wang Quanzhang, and their son, Qiaoqiao, last week. Mr. Wang, a lawyer at the Fengrui Law Firm in Beijing, was formally arrested last week, a colleague said.

item.title: Junior Doctors’ Strike in England Disrupts Care for Thousands
item.description: The first strike by medical doctors in the country in four decades heightened tensions over the stewardship of a widely revered health system that has come under growing strain.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: A striker during outside a London hospital on Tuesday.

item.title: Philippine Court Paves Way for U.S. to Extend Military Presence
item.description: The court ruled that a pact, which lets the United States build military facilities and maintain troops on a rotating basis, did not violate the Constitution.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:description: Protesters outside the Supreme Court in Manila on Tuesday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How to Help the Syrians Who Want to Return Home
item.description: The argument over admitting Syrian refugees obscures the bigger issue: How do we support those who want to return to Syria?
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: MAUREEN WHITE
item.media:description: A Syrian refugee in Lesbos, Greece.

item.title: As U.S. Modernizes Nuclear Weapons, ‘Smaller’ Leaves Some Uneasy
item.description: The Energy Department and the Pentagon have been readying a weapon with a build-it-smaller approach, setting off a philosophical clash in the world of nuclear arms.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: The new B61 Model 12 nuclear bomb.

item.title: Rupert Murdoch, News Corp. Chief, and Jerry Hall Announce Engagement
item.description: Mr. Murdoch, the media titan, and Ms. Hall, a former model, made the announcement in the classifieds of The Times of London, a newspaper Mr. Murdoch’s company owns.
item.dc:creator: ASHLEY SOUTHALL
item.media:description: Jerry Hall and Rupert Murdoch at the 73rd Golden Globes on Sunday.

item.title: El Chapo Case Draws Mexico Closer to U.S.
item.description: Joaquín Guzmán Loera’s escape from prison helped shrink the distance between Mexico and the United States, creating a sense of shared urgency that had not existed in years.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Soldiers on Sunday patrolling the perimeter of the prison outside Mexico City where Joaquín Guzmán Loera is being held.

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: American Woman Found Dead
item.description: Local news reports said the body of the woman, Ashley Ann Olsen, 35, was found in her bedroom on Saturday by her landlady and her boyfriend.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Iran Reports Removing Core From Reactor
item.description: Iran reported on Monday that it had removed the core of its plutonium-producing nuclear reactor at Arak as part of its efforts to complete its obligations under a new international agreement.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Convoys Enter Besieged Syrian Towns to Deliver Food and Medical Aid
item.description: Shipments of food and medical supplies inched toward four settlements amid an international outcry over the rising number of malnutrition deaths.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Syrians on Monday outside the rebel-held town of Madaya, which is besieged by pro-government forces including the Lebanese militia group Hezbollah.

item.title: News Analysis: Theatrics Surrounding El Chapo’s Capture Distract From Mexico’s Real Woes
item.description: The revelation that Sean Penn interviewed the fugitive drug trafficker gave some Mexicans further justification for their abiding cynicism toward government.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: On the run, Joaquín Guzmán Loera hoped to make a movie, but his plan led to his capture, officials said.

item.title: World Briefing: Conflicts Keep 24 Million Children Out of School, Unicef Report Finds
item.description: The highest proportion was in South Sudan, where more than half the school-age children are not in school.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: Court Held Lawmakers in Contempt
item.description: The opposition to President Nicolás Maduro and his party won a large majority in the Assembly, but some Socialist candidates filed lawsuits challenging the results.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Reactor Is Said to Be Disabled
item.description: Iran has removed the core of its plutonium-producing nuclear reactor at Arak and filled the space with cement, completing another critical obligation under its nuclear agreement.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Pistorius Files Appeal
item.description: Oscar Pistorius has appealed his conviction for murder in the killing of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Air Force General Says Russia Missile Defense ‘Very Serious’
item.description: Gen. Frank Gorenc, commander of Air Force operations in Europe and Africa, said the Russian strategy, known as anti-access/area denial, or A2/AD, was among the most worrisome trends he had seen.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Israel Faces New Brand of Terrorism, This Time From Young Settlers
item.description: Israel’s domestic security agency sees a group of young extremists from settlement outposts as being behind a wave of violence against Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Youths from the encampment of Baladim studying at the Maale Shlomo outpost in the West Bank. Shin Bet, the security service, has identified Baladim as a base where young Jewish activists formulated their radical agenda.

item.title: Princess Cristina of Spain Stands Trial in Tax Fraud Case
item.description: Cristina, the sister of King Felipe VI, is the first member of Spain’s royal family to stand trial, in a case that has become a major embarrassment for the Spanish monarchy.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
